title: How to Sew a Cutlery Roll

steps.headline: Assemble the items needed to complete this project.
steps.description: These are listed below under "Things You'll Need".

steps.headline: Place the tea towel laid out flat on the work surface.
steps.description: Fold the bottom end third of the way. Iron/press a crease. Then, fold the tea towel in half from the top. Iron this fold too, to form a sharp crease.

steps.headline: Cut the terry toweling or old hand towel to size.
steps.description: It needs to be one third the size of the folded tea towel. Pin this onto the tea towel at the back, through each layer. Line it up to the folded part.

steps.headline: Mark out the separate compartments for the cutlery.
steps.description: Along the length of the folded part of the tea towel, rule lines at intervals of around 2cm/just under an inch. Sew along each line through all layers, either by hand or by machine. This forms the cutlery compartments.

steps.headline: Once the compartments are sewn into place, sew the edge around the top part.
steps.description: Fold over the top third of the tea towel and sew all around the edge except for leaving one gap of 5cm/2.5"; this gap allows for turning around the right way. Trim each corner, then turn to the right side using the gap hole. Sew the gap up once turned.

steps.headline: Sew two fabric tie lengths on the middle of one edge of the cutlery roll.
steps.description: Use scrap fabric or ribbon as ties; you may need to sew the ties neatly down the length to prevent fraying (to do this, simply fold the edges to the center, iron into place, then sew).

steps.headline: Insert the cutlery.
steps.description: Roll up the roll and tie together using the ties.

text: Assemble the items needed to complete this project. These are listed below under "Things You'll Need". Place the tea towel laid out flat on the work surface. Fold the bottom end third of the way. Iron/press a crease. Then, fold the tea towel in half from the top. Iron this fold too, to form a sharp crease. Cut the terry toweling or old hand towel to size. It needs to be one third the size of the folded tea towel. Pin this onto the tea towel at the back, through each layer. Line it up to the folded part. Mark out the separate compartments for the cutlery. Along the length of the folded part of the tea towel, rule lines at intervals of around 2cm/just under an inch. Sew along each line through all layers, either by hand or by machine. This forms the cutlery compartments. Once the compartments are sewn into place, sew the edge around the top part. Fold over the top third of the tea towel and sew all around the edge except for leaving one gap of 5cm/2.5"; this gap allows for turning around the right way. Trim each corner, then turn to the right side using the gap hole. Sew the gap up once turned. Sew two fabric tie lengths on the middle of one edge of the cutlery roll. Use scrap fabric or ribbon as ties; you may need to sew the ties neatly down the length to prevent fraying (to do this, simply fold the edges to the center, iron into place, then sew). Insert the cutlery. Roll up the roll and tie together using the ties. Finished.
